text:
Hey everyone! Super excited that to say that I was chosen as a speaker for my work to give a talk on Julia! My group is quite tech savvy and are very interested in Julia. They are primarily focused on healthcare and have experience in R, Python, and SQL.

My talk's title - and overall theme - is "Building Bridges with Julia" and I will be chatting about what is it, how is it used, how easy or challenging it is to pick it up, why it is a valuable language, and where to find resources to learn or pick up those skills.

I have some ideas of what I am going to put together, but does anyone have any suggestions/advice on giving a talk on Julia? I'd love to hear your thoughts and I just had to share it with you all as I am pretty excited! :scream:

~ tcp :deciduous_tree:

My talk's title - and overall theme - is "Building Bridges with Julia" and I will be chatting about what is it, how is it used, how easy or challenging it is to pick it up, why it is a valuable language, and where to find resources to learn or pick up those skills.

I have some ideas of what I am going to put together, but does anyone have any suggestions/advice on giving a talk on Julia? I'd love to hear your thoughts and I just had to share it with you all as I am pretty excited!

text: my 2 cents: talk more about interoperability (PyCall, RCall, etc...) than speed.  I prefer to let the speed come as a nice surprise than overselling it and let people burn themselves with time to first plot

elements.text: my 2 cents: talk more about interoperability (PyCall, RCall, etc...) than speed.  I prefer to let the speed come as a nice surprise than overselling it and let people burn themselves with time to first plot

text: I believe showing that they don't need to throw away what they've used so far can go a long way convincing people migrating.  then they can get rid of the old tools and do everything in julia :smile:

elements.text: I believe showing that they don't need to throw away what they've used so far can go a long way convincing people migrating.  then they can get rid of the old tools and do everything in julia

text: Oh yea definitely - that's the whole idea of "Building Bridges with Julia". I am of the mind that Julia isn't really trying to take over the data science world but just do really great with the things it is focusing on while being able to play great with others.

text: A think a note about how powerful custom plot recipes are could be relevant. e.g. how WFDB has custom functionality for displaying physiological signals, but only if you use Matplotlib.

text: don't say it, show it. Don't say Julia is fast, show that Jonnie (NASA Launch Services) got a 15,000x acceleration switching from Simulink to ModelingToolkit. Show that 175x acceleration in Pfizer's QSP simulations. Octavian, etc. Whichever ones you like. And explain the high level of the technical details that made those specific pieces happen.
